title: Face Inventory
description: How many versions of you exist?

questions.question: How many distinctly different versions of yourself do you recognize existing?

options.text: Just one core self, broken into scattered pieces that don't always connect
A carefully curated collection, each designed for specific audiences and situations
A fluid, ever-changing self that adapts to whatever the moment requires
Multiple complete individuals sharing this body, each with their own lives
None - they're all illusions masking a fundamental emptiness

questions.question: When someone tells you to 'just be yourself,' what is your immediate internal response?

options.text: Panic because I don't know which fragment they want to see
Amusement at the impossibility - there is no authentic self to be
Confusion about which version of myself would be appropriate for this context
An internal conference as different selves debate who should take control
A hollow feeling as I realize there's nothing authentic to reveal

questions.question: Describe the relationship between your work personality and your home personality:

options.text: They're fragments of the same broken mirror, reflecting different angles
Professional actors playing completely different roles in separate productions
Fluid adaptations that shift so completely I sometimes forget which is real
Distinct individuals who would be strangers if they met at a party
Equally empty costumes draped over the same void

questions.question: Looking at old photographs of yourself feels most like:

options.text: Viewing a scattered timeline where different pieces of me existed at different times
Watching a portfolio of different characters I've portrayed over the years
Seeing evidence of my shape-shifting abilities across various life contexts
Meeting old friends - different people who lived in my body before
Looking at elaborate costumes that never quite concealed the nothingness beneath

questions.question: Your personality shifts and changes primarily based on:

options.text: Which broken piece of me is dominant in any given moment
What role the situation demands and which character can deliver it best
The social environment and what adaptation will ensure survival and acceptance
Which member of my internal community has stepped forward to handle things
Whatever temporary shape the void decides to take to fool observers

questions.question: When you're completely alone with no external expectations, you:

options.text: Feel the disconnected pieces of myself floating without coordination
Continue performing for an imaginary audience because stopping feels impossible
Feel lost without external cues to guide my adaptation
Experience internal conversations and negotiations between different selves
Confront the terrifying silence where a person should be

questions.question: If different friends were asked to describe your personality, they would:

options.text: Give descriptions that share common threads but emphasize different fragments
Describe completely different people as if they'd met different actors
Each describe the version of me that emerged in response to their energy
Be describing entirely different individuals who happen to live in the same body
Struggle to pin down anything concrete, sensing something missing or hollow

questions.question: Your internal monologue most resembles:

options.text: Fractured conversations between disconnected parts of the same person
A director constantly giving notes to the actor currently on stage
A constantly shifting voice that mirrors whoever I'm currently around
A lively committee meeting with distinct voices advocating different positions
White noise punctuated by echoes of other people's thoughts

questions.question: If your childhood self met your current self, they would think:

options.text: I became scattered and lost pieces of who I was supposed to be
I became an expert at playing whatever game was required to survive
I learned to become whoever was needed in each moment
I multiplied into many people instead of growing into one
I disappeared entirely, leaving only an elaborate illusion behind

questions.question: In romantic relationships, your biggest challenge is:

options.text: Showing someone all my broken pieces without overwhelming them
Maintaining consistent character performance across intimate moments
Not losing myself completely in adapting to what they want
Helping them understand they're in relationship with multiple people
The fear that intimacy will reveal there's nothing real to love

questions.question: Your emotions feel like they belong to:

options.text: Different aspects of the same fractured person, not always in communication
Whatever character is currently performing, fitting the role requirements
The person I'm unconsciously mirroring or adapting to match
Specific individuals within me, each with their own emotional patterns
Nobody in particular - borrowed feelings filling an empty space

questions.question: Making important life decisions is difficult because:

options.text: Different fragments of me want incompatible things
I don't know which character should be making the choice
My preferences shift depending on who I'm consulting or what context I'm in
I need to get consensus from multiple internal voices with different agendas
Nothing feels authentically desired when there's no authentic self to want it

questions.question: Your voice, mannerisms, and way of speaking change based on:

options.text: Which piece of my fractured self is currently dominant
Which persona I'm channeling for this particular performance
Unconscious mimicry of whoever I'm around or trying to connect with
Which member of my internal community is currently speaking
Whatever temporary voice seems most likely to convince people I exist

questions.question: Your hobbies, interests, and passions:

options.text: Belong to different fragments and sometimes conflict with each other
Were consciously chosen to support various character portrayals
Shift and evolve based on my social environment and the people I'm around
Are distinct to different internal individuals, creating a rich but chaotic mix
Feel borrowed or adopted rather than authentically chosen

questions.question: When you look in mirrors, you most often see:

options.text: A kaleidoscope of different versions overlapping and competing for space
Today's costume and character, wondering how convincing the performance is
Whatever version of myself is emerging in response to the current context
Different faces depending on who's looking back at that moment
A very convincing mask over an absence that makes me uncomfortable

questions.question: Your memories feel like they:

options.text: Belong to different versions of me, some more accessible than others
Are scenes from various movies I've starred in over the years
Shift in meaning and emotional tone depending on my current adaptation
Are owned by different internal people, like a shared photo album
Are stories about nobody in particular, lacking a central protagonist

questions.question: When someone asks you to describe yourself, you:

options.text: Struggle to present a coherent picture from all the scattered pieces
Automatically assess what version they want to hear about
Describe whoever I'm being in response to their energy and expectations
Wonder which member of my internal community should answer
Feel like I'm describing a fictional character that doesn't really exist

questions.question: Your sense of core identity could best be described as:

options.text: A shattered mirror where each piece reflects part of the whole truth
A master director coordinating multiple character performances
A fluid intelligence that adapts its shape to survive any environment
A collective consciousness housing multiple complete individuals
An elegant absence masquerading as presence

questions.question: In group social settings, you tend to:

options.text: Let different fragments handle different people, creating a complex social mosaic
Perform a carefully chosen character that fits the group's energy and expectations
Become a social shapeshifter, adapting moment by moment to group dynamics
Experience internal negotiations about who should represent us in this context
Feel myself becoming more transparent until I'm barely there at all

questions.question: Your ideal version of yourself would be:

options.text: All my pieces integrated into one cohesive, whole person
The perfect method actor who could embody any role flawlessly
Someone who could adapt to any situation while maintaining a core sense of self
A harmonious collective where all internal voices cooperate and communicate well
Actually real for once, instead of an elaborate simulation of personhood

questions.question: Sleep and rest are challenging because:

options.text: Different parts of me have different sleep needs and schedules
I can't stop performing even when there's no audience
Without external cues, I don't know who I'm supposed to be while sleeping
Internal conversations and negotiations continue even when I try to rest
The emptiness becomes most apparent when there are no distractions

questions.question: Your greatest fear about identity is:

options.text: That my scattered pieces will never come together into a whole person
That someone will see through all my performances to the emptiness behind them
That I'll adapt so completely I'll lose track of any original self
That my internal community will fragment into conflict or someone will be lost
That there was never anyone there to begin with

questions.question: Most of your daily mental energy goes toward:

options.text: Managing conflicts and communication between different parts of myself
Maintaining consistent character performance across different contexts
Constantly reading and adapting to my environment and the people in it
Facilitating internal negotiations and decision-making processes
Maintaining the illusion of existence when I feel fundamentally empty

questions.question: If all your different faces/selves met in a room together, what would happen?

options.text: They'd struggle to communicate, like fragments trying to remember how to be whole
They'd compare notes on their performances and debate which approach works best
They'd shift and adapt to each other until nobody remembered their original form
They'd have a lively discussion like old friends with different specialties
The room would appear empty despite all the elaborate costumes on the chairs

questions.question: When you try to answer the question 'Who am I really?', what happens?

options.text: I get fragments of answers that don't quite fit together into a complete picture
I realize I'm the director, not the actors - the one creating all the performances
The answer changes depending on when and where I ask the question
Multiple voices answer simultaneously, each giving a different but valid response
I encounter a profound silence where an answer should be

traits.title: The Fractured Mirror
traits.description: Your identity exists in pieces, each fragment reflecting a different truth, none of them whole. You're not one person pretending to be many - you're many people fighting to be one. The cracks between your selves run deep, creating a mosaic of contradictions that somehow forms the pattern of your existence.

traits.title: The Method Actor
traits.description: Life is your stage, and you've forgotten which role was originally yours. Every interaction is a performance, every relationship a carefully scripted scene. You've become so good at being who others need that you've lost track of who you need to be for yourself.

traits.title: The Social Chameleon
traits.description: You don't just adapt - you transform. Your personality is liquid, flowing into whatever shape the moment requires. This isn't mere people-pleasing; it's survival through metamorphosis. You've evolved past having a fixed identity, becoming instead a living response to your environment.

traits.title: The Hollow Vessel
traits.description: Where others have identity, you have absence. You're not fractured or performing - you're fundamentally empty, a human-shaped void that fills itself with echoes of others. This isn't depression or dissociation; it's deeper - you suspect that if all the borrowed pieces were removed, there would be nothing left.

traits.title: The Legion Self
traits.description: You are not one, you are many. Not masks or fragments, but fully formed identities sharing a single body. Each has their own wants, fears, and memories. They negotiate for control, form alliances, wage internal wars. You're less a person than a democracy of selves.
